statement.text: Popliteal artery disease occurs at mechanically stressed segments - the adductor canal and trifurcation - and determines bypass target selection, with disease extent classified as above-knee (P1), across-knee (P2), or below-knee (P3) segments.
statement.formal: Segments: P1 (above-knee) → P2 (knee joint) → P3 (below-knee to trifurcation); Key consideration: Distal landing zone quality determines bypass durability

explanation.intuition: The popliteal artery passes through a mechanically demanding region - compressed and flexed with every step. Disease concentrates at stress points, and understanding these patterns guides where to place bypass grafts or stents.
explanation.key_insight: A diseased popliteal artery may require targeting the tibial trifurcation or tibial vessels for bypass - always assess below the popliteal.
explanation.technical_details: The popliteal artery is divided into three segments: P1 (above-knee, from adductor hiatus to femoral condyles), P2 (at knee joint level), and P3 (below-knee, from knee joint to trifurcation). Atherosclerosis commonly affects the adductor canal (SFA-popliteal junction) and the trifurcation. Popliteal aneurysms are also common and can cause acute limb ischemia. Treatment planning must account for flexion stress and landing zone quality.
common_misconceptions: All femoropopliteal bypasses end above the knee - FALSE, below-knee targets often needed
Popliteal stenting has good outcomes - FALSE, high restenosis rates, especially across knee
Popliteal disease is the same as SFA disease - FALSE, different mechanical environment
P1, P2, P3 segments don't affect treatment choice - FALSE, landing zone selection is critical

p1_above_knee.location: Adductor hiatus to superior margin of femoral condyles

p2_at_knee.characteristics: Maximum flexion stress, worst for stenting

p3_below_knee.location: Below knee joint to tibioperoneal trunk

trifurcation.tibioperoneal_trunk: Short segment giving PT and peroneal
trifurcation.disease_pattern: Common site of severe calcification and occlusion

femoropopliteal_disease.extension: SFA disease often extends into popliteal

isolated_popliteal.evaluation: Consider non-atherosclerotic causes in young patients

popliteal_aneurysm.definition: Diameter >1.5 cm or 50% larger than proximal artery

bypass_planning.landing_zone: Target disease-free segment with adequate runoff
bypass_planning.above_knee_target: P1 segment, better patency with vein
bypass_planning.below_knee_target: P3 segment or tibial vessels if disease extends

concerns: High fracture rates at P2 (across knee)
stenting.recommendation: Avoid stenting across knee; reserved for selected cases

conduit_selection.below_knee: Vein strongly preferred, prosthetic poor outcomes

definition.@value: Patterns of atherosclerotic disease affecting the popliteal artery segments, critical for bypass planning and revascularization strategy.

presentation: Combined thigh and calf symptoms if SFA involved

sources.reference: SVS Practice Guidelines for Lower Extremity Bypass

learning_objectives: Identify the three segments of the popliteal artery (P1, P2, P3)
Explain why P2 segment stenting has poor outcomes
Plan bypass based on disease-free landing zone
Recognize popliteal aneurysm and its complications
clinical_pearls: P2 (across knee) is worst for stenting - high fracture rates
Always assess trifurcation patency before planning bypass
50% of popliteal aneurysms are bilateral - check both sides
Young patient with popliteal disease = consider entrapment/adventitial cyst
Below-knee popliteal bypass requires vein conduit
